title: Haus Der Architektur Graz
segmentation: Thank you very much.
First of all, thank you so much.
The ocean to mow theme for this great initiative and for being such a marvelous hosts.
My name is Marcus books back I'm the director of the House of Architecture in Gratz.
And I would like to.
Tell you a little bit about the sum of architecture with this last year.
It's and of course not.
You can't compare this with the Lisa Pandarian are it is small scale project and more on a local base.
I'm a little bit about the House of Architecture.

It was established in 1988 and it was established by the major players in the field of architecture in crowds, the faculty, the city of Crowds, then the province of stereo Chamber of Architects Form start back, which is a kind of cultural institution and its intra finding which is a kind of old guys gap about architecture.
And the meaning of the House of Architecture was to generate the platform for architectural discourse.
Grass is a very lovely architecture scene.
We have around 2000 architecture students and about 400 architectural offices and in the surrounding it's 500 offices.
So we have to deal with about 5000 people working in the field of architecture, which is kind of.
Own audience by itself, yeah, and.
So the beginning of the House of Architecture was in this kind of closed circuit of people already dealing with architecture and.
But times are changing, so although the role of the House of Architecture was changing, we moved into the city center and into this old Barack Ballet.
Basically, we just have to ground floor, so we are really quite small institution.
Also, the discourse about architecture changed in this period of time, yeah?

The turnbuckle door came up, which means that the deal with architecture in a broader understanding, yeah, also considering the whole social background, how architecture is produced and also what's between architecture and also did the term architecture for mid long, which means mediation of architecture came more important so.
And also that the topics which.
What is within the architecture community?
Got much more broader?
Yeah, the sustainability debate and public space became a very important issue.
Mobility, also, social inclusion and all these things which.
Affect us every day.
So we had the task more or less to get out of our comfort zone and broaden update this course in a way.
So we thought that maybe it's a good idea to do this architecture summer summer of architecture.
And of course, this is not a genuine idea.

In Germany we have different architectures, summers and also we had the kind of reference project which is the hamburger headache this summer, which is also very bottom up, so it's not kind of created thing.
It's.
Done by.
Lots of initiatives who combined their forces.
So how did we do it at the project phase was just a little bit more than 1 1/2 years.
So very short and the beginning was a kind of open call.
Who wants to take part and the basic idea was to do something which is underrated.
And which sees architecture as a really transdisciplinary subject in those approach.
Check it.
So we choose that we won't take theme title, that it's absolutely not the commercial and that it's not a new festival or that it doesn't try to institutionalise itself.

So the idea was really to address the broader audience and which was also the almost of the same importance to generate a network among stakeholders here, because there are really lots of people working in this field of architecture.
If you see it in a broader context which don't communicate with each other, there are theater groups who deal with the living conditions in.
So in housing areas there are social sociologists who deal with public space.
Lots of people are doing really professional work in this field, but they normally they don't communicate with each other, and so we tried to bring them all.
Together in this kind of in this specified time period from June to September in 2015.

So we started to invite people and met them over a period of time which was already very interesting because very different people got together and talked about what's what's going on basically, and we also did this kind of public meetings where we discussed the project idea and also presented what?
But our intentions were.
Um?

So in the end, after the open call we had 120 organizers, which is quite a lot and it turned out that we could generate in this way 280 events and because we are not just limited to crowds, it was in 18 cities in whole throughout stereo.
This is the province, the background sister capital.
So we really were surprised in the way that the feedback was that good and that we could generate this kind of mass of people who wanted to come to contribute to this project.
Did the we we had just funding for for the kind of organization of this whole thing?
We couldn't give funds to people who participated, so all the program was generated through the normal things people are ready to maybe just a little bit.
They shifted the program their normal programs on this special architectural again there and there were lots of initiatives who just.
Took the chance to do something here and they generated their funding by applications or by doing just things with their own money and effort.
So this was a main communication tool.
With this program.

A small booklet with which we produced in a high number and the idea was that it lies on the kitchen table for the whole summer and that you have a look inside if you want to do something and you can see OK there are three exhibitions and two guided tours and so very.
Instant Dennis approach.
The second thing was to the website, which was very simple.
It just gave you an overview.

It was basically a calendar where you could choose the program with places, categories and also we had some a few other features like a block which documented what was going on during this period of time.
The whole communication the graphics were focused on Everyday's life.
Yeah, so we really wanted to.
Make simple statements like the left one is we're all living in architecture, the right one is whether the everyday is at home.
So we also the pictures we used were not specifically what you consider as architectural.
But this was we wanted to create this kind of tension between everyday and the term architecture also because.
Architecture is still on the.
A term which is quite problematic if you talk to people.
Normal people who don't think that they are affected by architecture in a way.
So we also made the kind of.
So this.
Is both the series in on places which are significant in Kratz?
And The thing is, was that we had really at low budget.
But we talk to.
And.
Specific people who helped us out.
For example the the public transport became partner of ours, and so they they made this kind of posters in every bus.
In every tram.
It was on all these kind of info screens, so we will absolutely pull funding.
We made a big.
Appearance in the in the city.
And we also had a public funding.
This is the cultural ministere of stereo who had it.
This place in the whole thing.
So we also got buses and this kind of things for free so we could drive around people during the summer months, which was very a very good thing to bring at some life.
It programs this post from the.
Opening event we went on the high rooftops of the city also to communicate that we want to shift the few of everyday.
Yeah so if you change your angle of view you can generate knowledge in a way.
So this was the kind of symbolic start for.
Cold thing.
Done.
We also focused on a younger audience.
So we generated kind of events which are also popular.
And this worked out very well, because the House of Architecture is similar to other cultural institutions really sometimes have troubles with getting in touch with a younger audience.
And for us this was a kind of starting point to intensify this relationship again.
Then we establish a recall that communication zone, which was a modular furniture which could.
Be used in different ways here.
For example, for a workshop, workshops were very important for us because we wanted to generate situations which continue afterwards.
This, for example, is a workshop with.
Did much China also from the architecture Centromin in Vienna.
It was about writing about architecture, so young people went to this workshops, which was they were also additional.
Very high profile teachers and they they.
They made texts about the current situation of the architectural situation in greatest area, so they were involved in in a deeper thinking about what is going on.
The same was happening with the photograph.
Workshops and also the city of Gratz jumped in and they made, for example, workshops about.
Reusing voids and different things.
So we really came into a kind of process of involving.
People and generating things which went on afterwards.
Of course we tried to address also the very young.
People together with the Association called Kinda Friday we made the city of children for one week where there about 200 children per birthday.
Simulated city life with election of mayors and the City planning Department and and everything you can imagine which worked out very well.
And all events tried to be kind of girls to do the reality.
For example, we made this kind of beer garden of film screening.
And this was a series of things.
The House of Architecture was open as we hosted events for the whole period of time, so we had about 2 three events per week at this and also short exhibitions lectures.
Lots of things going on in the House of Architecture itself, but the the program was channel.
Rated by people from the outside and it was very interesting for us to see that.
Small groups of people found themselves.
For example, this is a project which was dealt with public space.
How to get in touch with other people in public space?
These guys also made an exhibition out of there.
Of this install, public space installation asking additional artists to join in, and they also went on with their program to the Urban Arts Festival in Vienna.
So then things went into.
Kept on.
Rolling in a way.
The summer was very nice, so.
People use this the architecture summer too.
They do lots of stuff in the in the in the open air.
And.
For example, this is moving cinema which used facades in the city to make to show short films about architect.
One main point was.
Was guided to US and the spectrum of guided.
This was extremely broad, from historic.
Thanks to interest.
Picture of visiting building sites.
Or opening of houses.
So there was really an extreme broad spectrum of.
I did this and also to Slovenia we.
Make this kind of work from from across the border at the Slovenian border, which dealt with the Urban Development after the.
The fall of the the Iron Curtain.
In this.
Region.
Yep, as adult it we there are really lots of events going on and.
And in the end it showed that we didn't really have to create it.
Yeah, people understood what was our.
Intention, and really the devil's absolutely no program which fell out of the totally fell out of this framework.
There were also some interesting situations.
For example, one artist said this is the right point to to make his installation.
He always wanted to do.
They made this crazy bubble in the city center, which is a reference to the House Ruka.
Why is the number 7 of them?
And basically it's a banana plant, ash, which gets its energy from a pizzeria beneath.

So this is a quite interesting project by young Architects who said they will do a mobile architectural office and travel across stereo and do this sign for food and drinks, which was a very which worked out very well and it was.
So inspiring that they did all the movie out of it and all these things still continue.
We also tried to address kind of urgent issues like the vast areas or empty.
Empty shops in the in the city of Gratz, this wasn't a.
And pop-up Gallery, which wandered which changed the location during the time period and.
Show photographs about urban issues.
Young there was.
Exhibitions.
And we were very happy that that also bigger institutions joined in.
Of course, the time period was too short to do really big exhibitions.
But considering the this short amount of time we had for preparations that really worked out very well.
The immediate response was extremely good.
We had no money to replace our ads or something and I don't know how it is in Slovenia, but in Australia it's like that.
If you don't pay for at the media, you don't exist in a way, yeah?
We tried, we had a very strong communication with the.
With the cultural editors of the.
Um, almost all newspapers, daily newspapers and also of the Austrian broadcasting Company.
So we really were in the.
Got good coverage this for example Articleship which were in the Corona setting which is a kind of yellow press format.
We had a weekly feature at this newspaper which is the major newspaper in in Austria.
Very critical newspaper.
Difficult newspaper, but we if you have to pay for it, it costs you can't afford it.
Yeah?
So we we got it.
All for free.
And yeah.
So basically we had around 20,000 visitors.
And 280 events with 120 contributors and.
The the the effect also is that we really could increase the communication between the actors in this field.
So we really got a totally new connections between different different people and we also feel it every day in the House of Architecture we are very small institution.
We always get every week invitation to sign the letter of interest or participate in.
In programs, so we really could achieve to get this kind of a step out from our small institution from the small architectural world into a broader.
Discourse.
Yeah.
That's it.
Thank you very much.
